docs.lead_paragraph: America regards itself as an eminently civilized country, but in many states female prisoners who give birth are required to be held in shackles during labor. Besides being grotesquely inhumane, this appalling practice is medically dangerous. A report by Amnesty International U.S.A. finds that nearly half the state corrections departments -- and the Federal Bureau of Prisons -- have policies that expressly permit this practice. Prison officials justify the policy by saying that the women are a flight risk, even though many of them are nonviolent offenders who would present little risk, even if they were not doubled over with labor pains or strapped down on a delivery table.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that primitive practice of chaining female prisoners in childbirth should shame us all
docs.snippet: The primitive practice of chaining female prisoners in childbirth should shame us all.

docs.lead_paragraph: Abortion politics takes place on the grand stage, like the Supreme Court, but also behind closed doors, in this case at the Food and Drug Administration. The F.D.A. has not approved over-the-counter sales of Plan B, an emergency ''morning after'' contraceptive opposed by many abortion foes, who consider it tantamount to ending a pregnancy.
docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration has not approved over-the-counter sales of Plan B, emergency 'morning after' contraceptive opposed by many abortion foes; Dr Susan F Wood, director of FDA's office of women's health, resigned in Aug 2005 because of what she said was politicization of Plan B decision (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: SIDNEY POITIER was the first Walter Lee Younger. He played the role in the 1959 Broadway production of ''A Raisin in the Sun'' and in the 1961 film. With an actor of such immense, restrained power, there was no doubt that the play Lorraine Hansberry had written was Walter's story. He represented a changing consciousness among black Americans as the civil rights movement lay right around the corner. These things are not so clear in Hartford Stage's new production, although it is a solid, frequently entertaining show. Billy Eugene Jones, who had a small part in the 2004 Broadway revival (in which Sean Combs, a k a Diddy, played the male lead), plays Walter here.

headline.main: A 'Raisin' With Appeal, if Not Crystal Clarity

docs.lead_paragraph: Relenting to pressure from state government officials, Wal-Mart Stores said yesterday that it would begin carrying Plan B, an emergency contraception pill, in all of its United States pharmacies by the end of the month. But in a move that rankled some women's groups, Wal-Mart said that it would allow pharmacists who object to filling a Plan B prescription to refer customers to another pharmacist and, in some cases, to another pharmacy.

headline.main: In Reversal, Wal-Mart Will Sell Contraceptive

docs.abstract: Wal-Mart Stores, relenting to pressure from state officials, says it will begin carrying Plan B, emergency contraception pill, in all of its US pharmacies by end of month; will allow pharmacists who object to filling Plan B prescriptions to refer customers to another pharmacist and, in some cases, to another pharmacy (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Personal Health column in Science Times on Feb. 21, about depression and pregnancy, used an incorrect estimate from a medical journal for the number of women affected. As many as 800,000 women in the United States each year suffer moderate to severe depression during pregnancy -- not 80,000.
docs.abstract: Correction of Feb 21 Personal Health column on depression and pregnancy

docs.lead_paragraph: AS pregnancies progress, women are vulnerable to back pain, and that may discourage them from doing 30 minutes of moderate exercise most, if not all, days of the week as the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends. So it helps to have workout clothes that not only accommodate mothers' ever-changing stomachs but also cradle them enough to alleviate pressure on their lower backs. ''Once I started showing, it was hard to find comfortable clothing that gave me proper support,'' said Caroline Brozak, 40, a New Yorker who swam, cycled and did yoga through her pregnancy.

headline.main: Physical Culture; Working Out While Baby Grows

docs.abstract: Workout clothing for pregnant women reviewed; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Shawanna Nelson, a prisoner at the McPherson Unit in Newport, Ark., had been in labor for more than 12 hours when she arrived at Newport Hospital on Sept. 20, 2003. Ms. Nelson, whose legs were shackled together and who had been given nothing stronger than Tylenol all day, begged, according to court papers, to have the shackles removed. Though her doctor and two nurses joined in the request, her lawsuit says, the guard in charge of her refused.

headline.main: Prisons Often Shackle Pregnant Inmates in Labor

docs.snippet: Corrections officials say they must strike a balance between security and the well-being of the pregnant woman and her child.
